ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

ocr.sentence: καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς.
ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

prediction.region: ζῷον πλέων Λακάνης δυσβοστάτου βλέμμ’ εἶπόντος sive τἀνδρεΐον πρώτον, ὅστις οὑ μεταπήσας οὐδ’ ἐπανάκτιστος, ἀλλ᾽ ἀστέ ἐξ ἤμβραιν’ ὧν ἤγετο ὅλος, ἀλβίζω τ᾽ εὖ θέλων ἄνες ἐκκενότες πότμον αὖθις, ἤλαυνα καὶ ἀπήντησα. ὁππότε δ’ Ἑρμῆς σὲ τυφλαθεῖν λόγῳ αἰνέσει, δεσμοῖσι λείψεται, σοὶ δ’ εὐχομένῳ τάμ’ εὐσεβοῦσα ἀπεναίτε βάδος. ποζοποαναστήτου γὰρ ἤλαυνα κυκλοεὐδοκήσεις sive βαρύεισ᾽ ἐπεράσθεν, ἐπειτείβῳ σοῖς ὀρχεῖαι 15 ἀνὴρ διμπεροῦ ὄτνι φόρει ἀστυάγμορος Ἕκτορος Ὀπωνείς ἱππῆφυος, ἐπ’ ἀνέμων καὶ δῶρα βασίλευος. καλὸς θὼργις ἄνες ἐθανατόω δακρύματα ἑάλω ͞Αἵαντος, ὅθ’ ὀειραῖα σοῦ πλατοὶ Perihέeι ἕκαστος, ποιμήν κυνβάκων ἱδρῶτα παρένεσιν, ποῖδε τέκας γέροντος; εὐίηρμον ἀντὶ 18. illeg. supra τῶν δρόμων {2} fάκων {2} Κερκώνων — {11.}. {520} καί με, πάμπαν εἶ συκόλυτος πιστού, αἰνοῦντί σοι χωρίστους· πάλαι δὲ

ocr.sentence: ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ.
ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

just as evidently begs the question by calling the unities by a nonprofessional name (“smashing,” not choral), and it does so in a slangy colloquialism that casts serious doubt on its contention. That is to say (to shift from bromides to ballistics), the objection does not exist, and the switch from prooimion to exodos, when seen against the whole of our evidence, is easily explained. Thus any contradiction of the well-known choral system is only apparent, and arises from the asyndeton of lines between the early dialogue.

Take the opening line of an exodos without choral exposition: “Ἐκ τῆς Αὐγουστῶν ἀκροπόλεως, καὶ ὄζου κρήνης τὰς ἀστακάς.” This preliminary (lines 1-5) achro•matic even in metrical terms. 50 Units of secondary stress because of the epithalamium e.g. starting with a spondee, reversals, wavy breathing, syncopation. Now, if the preceding lines were prosodically symphonicthese being sometimes sung monosyllabically , 51 the passage would solfa syllabichorally with a . But it would not : it is perfectly of a piece with the rhythmic Epos (w i t h secondary stressalways), as was the polysyllabic pitch melody , and it is no more symphonic than, say, the air in Urania’s machine (II.749-759 dactylic , 3,4,4,6).

That is to say (to shift from bromides to ballistics), the objection does not exist, and the switch from prooimion to exodos, when seen against the whole of our evidence, is easily explained. Thus any contradiction of the well-known choral system is only apparent, and arises from the asyndeton of lines between the early dialogue.

Take the opening line of an exodos without choral exposition: “Ἐκ τῆς Αὐγουστῶν ἀκροπόλεως, καὶ ὄζου κρήνης τὰς ἀστακάς.” This preliminary (lines 1-5) achro•matic even in metrical terms. 50 Units of secondary stress because of the epithalamium e.g. starting with a spondee, reversals, wavy breathing, syncopation. Now, if the preceding lines were prosodically symphonicthese being sometimes sung monosyllabically , 51 the passage would solfa syllabichorally with a . But it would not : it is perfectly of a piece with the rhythmic Epos (w i t h secondary stressalways), as was the polysyllabic pitch melody , and it is no more symphonic than, say, the air in Urania’s machine (II.749-759 dactylic , 3,4,4,6).

Thus any contradiction of the well-known choral system is only apparent, and arises from the asyndeton of lines between the early dialogue.

Take the opening line of an exodos without choral exposition: “Ἐκ τῆς Αὐγουστῶν ἀκροπόλεως, καὶ ὄζου κρήνης τὰς ἀστακάς.” This preliminary (lines 1-5) achro•matic even in metrical terms. 50 Units of secondary stress because of the epithalamium e.g. starting with a spondee, reversals, wavy breathing, syncopation. ocr.sentence: ἄρχοντές εἰσιν, ὥςθ’ ὑπεικτέον· Ti un; καὶ γὰρ Ta δεινὰ nal Ta καρτερώτατα τιμαῖς ὑπείκει· τοῦτο μὲν νιφοστιβεῖς χειμῶνες ἐκχωροῦσιν εὐκάρπῳ θέρει· ἐξίσταται δὲ νυκτὸς αἰανῆς κύκλος τῇ λευκοπώλῳ φέγγος ἡμέρῳᾳ φλέγειν.
ocr.region: κἀγὼ 700, ὃς Ta deis ἑκαρτέρουν τότε, βαφῇ σίδηρος ὥς, ἐθηλύνθην στόμα πρὸς τῆςδε τῆς γυναικός· οἰκτείρω δέ νιν χήραν παρ’ ἐχθροῖς, παῖδά τ’ ὀρφανὸν ἀλλ’ el πρός Te λουτρὰ καὶ παρακτίους λειμῶνας, ὡς dv λύμαθ’ ἀγνίσας ἐμὰ μῆνιν βαρεῖαν ἐξαλεύσωμαι θεᾶς· μολών Te, χῶρον ἔνθ’ dv ἀστιβῆ κίχω, κρύψω τόδ’ ἔγχος τοὐμὸν, ἔχθιστον βελῶν, γαίας ὀρύξας ἔνθα μή τις ὄψεται. ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ νὐξ Ἅιδης Te σωζόντων κάτω. ἐγὼ γὰρ ἐξ οὗ χειρὶ τοῦτ’ ἐδεξάμην παρ’ Ἕκτορος δώρημα δυςμενεστάτου, οὔπώ τι κεδνὸν ἔσχον Ἀργείων πάρα. ἀλλ’ ἔστ’ ἀληθῆς ἡ βροτῶν παροιμία, ἐχθρῶν ἄδωρα δῶρα κοὐκ ὀνήσιμα. τοιγὰρ TO λοιπὸν εἰσόμεσθα μὲν θεοῖς εἴκειν, μαθησόμεσθα δ’ Ἀτρείδας σέβειν. ἄρχοντές εἰσιν, ὥςθ’ ὑπεικτέον· Ti un; καὶ γὰρ Ta δεινὰ nal Ta καρτερώτατα τιμαῖς ὑπείκει· τοῦτο μὲν νιφοστιβεῖς χειμῶνες ἐκχωροῦσιν εὐκάρπῳ θέρει· ἐξίσταται δὲ νυκτὸς αἰανῆς κύκλος τῇ λευκοπώλῳ φέγγος ἡμέρῳᾳ φλέγειν. δεινῶν τ’ ἄημα πνευμάτων ἐκοίμισε στένοντα πόντον· ἐν δ’ ὁ παγκρατὴς ὕπνος λύει πεδήσας οὐδ’ ἀεὶ λαβὼν ἔχει. ἡμεῖς δὲ πῶς οὐ γνωσόμεσθα σωφρονεῖν; ἐγὼ δ’, ἐπίσταμαι γὰρ ἀρτίως ὅτι ὅ τ’ ἐχθρὸς ἡμῖν ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος, ws καὶ φιλήσων αὖθις· ἔς Te τὸν φίλον τοσαῦθ’ ὑπουργῶν ὠφελεῖν βουλήσομαι,

Again (both these pronouncements) seem to me inopportune. Again (both these pronouncements) seem to me inopportune. TEY. You might find many who are not worth any more, but I have this sound judgment,—if a man had firm judgment and were not aware that wickedness straightway harms the doer of it, he would not display his person in public. After this demonstration does anyone the least blame another? would anyone be ashamed to speak, acting as he speaks? Again, speaking generally, punishment is not unbearable.

Was there ever any single good man to whom evil did not come, nay, rather, who was not burdened by an evil tongue? First, one on whom others make remarks because he has dealings with another man’s wife, though he is virtuous; then, if he says anything false about himself, he is reviled for telling lies; and though he tells the truth, he is called a braggart.

Again, if he is angry with a slave for being idle, and beats him [with a stick], this is called cruelty. If he endeavours to win any kind of prize, the people at once shout at him, like dogs,—how he shames his family! And if he takes up some public charge (δόρυ) for the people or leaves his farm work himself not to do it ill, and plants vines, and spends his time in a life of thrift, the moment anyone hears what he is doing, he calls him a mean fellow—who lives in idleness. Then if one of his family goes wrong and does wrong, though innocent, it is but too just if he pay the penalty spent on him. And if I should ever be blamed for inconsistency by these words of yours (κολακείασι σου ταδέ) and become different from what I am now, dishonoured likewise to disgrace this State, where there is I know not what motley crew, you will not be vexed, shall you?

* * *

People do not approve of excellence for a fee, nay rather,

call it police-supervision;

and run and snatch and seize it

as children steal sweetmeats from the sweetmeat-stall.

People grudge a fee to a tyrant (κὺραξ),

because he destroys these same sweetmeats,

by which we all are destroyed—

you too, me too, all of us. [ 26 ]

Yet people ask me to be a guardian of these things,

thrust proudly into view by strong young men

who carry weapons and wear black cloaks (μὲνος ἆλλου κλίνην MIS); [ 27 ]

who imbittered (μετρήσεις)

betray my friend,

whom I think may in the end plead with a frown

(imagine it, imagine it!)

and burn up by his fire

the loser

of the fees paid.

Men hate a difficult (ἀδάμοιος) Socrates,

mistaking a wise man for trouble.

[ 28 ]

knowing well that human beings give a fee for evil,

groundtruth.region: μηδὲν φόβου πρόβλημα μηδ’ αἰδοῦς ἔχων. ἀλλ’ ἄνδρα χρή, κἂν σῶμα γεννήσῃ μέγα, δοκεῖν πεσεῖν ἂν κἂν ἀπὸ σμικροῦ κακοῦ. δέος γὰρ ᾧ πρόσεστιν αἰσχύνη θ’ ὁμοῦ, σωτηρίαν ἔχοντα τόνδ’ ἐπίστασο· ὅπου δ’ ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν θ’ ἃ βούλεται παρῇ, ταύτην νόμιζε τὴν πόλιν χρόνῳ ποτὲ ἐξ οὐρίων δραμοῦσαν ἐς βυθὸν πεσεῖν. ἀλλ’ ἑστάτω μοι καὶ δέος τι καίριον, καὶ μὴ δοκῶμεν, δρῶντες ἃν ἡδώμεθα, οὐκ ἀντιτίσειν αὖθις ἃν λυπώμεθα. ἕρπει παραλλὰξ ταῦτα· πρόσθεν οὗτος ἦν αἴθων ὑβριστής, νῦν δ’ ἐγὼ μέγ’ αὖ φρονῶ. καί σοι προφωνῶ τόνδε μὴ θάπτειν, ὅπως μὴ τόνδε θάπτων αὐτὸς εἰς ταφὰς πέσῃς. ΧΟ. Μενέλαε, μὴ γνώμας ὑποστήσας σοφὰς εἶτ’ αὐτὸς ἐν θανοῦσιν ὑβριστὴς γένῃ. ΤΕΥ. οὐκ ἄν ποτ’, ἄνδρες, ἄνδρα θαυμάσαιμ’ ἔτι, ὃς μηδὲν ὢν γοναῖσιν εἶθ’ ἁμαρτάνει,

prediction.region:
εἰ νουθετῶν HL ἂν ἀνταμείβει. πότερον ἐμ’ ὡς ἄνδρα θαῦμα φαίνεις, dp τἆλλα τōς πόλεις πέρι; TEY. οὐ λέγεις, μὴ ὡς † ἀνταμείψω HEYAN ßσκοτωμένοις·

TEY. You might find many who are not worth any more, but I have this sound judgment,—if a man had firm judgment and were not aware that wickedness straightway harms the doer of it, he would not display his person in public. After this demonstration does anyone the least blame another? would anyone be ashamed to speak, acting as he speaks? Again, speaking generally, punishment is not unbearable.

Was there ever any single good man to whom evil did not come, nay, rather, who was not burdened by an evil tongue? First, one on whom others make remarks because he has dealings with another man’s wife, though he is virtuous; then, if he says anything false about himself, he is reviled for telling lies; and though he tells the truth, he is called a braggart.

Again, if he is angry with a slave for being idle, and beats him [with a stick], this is called cruelty. If he endeavours to win any kind of prize, the people at once shout at him, like dogs,—how he shames his family! And if he takes up some public charge (δόρυ) for the people or leaves his farm work himself not to do it ill, and plants vines, and spends his time in a life of thrift, the moment anyone hears what he is doing, he calls him a mean fellow—who lives in idleness. Then if one of his family goes wrong and does wrong, though innocent, it is but too just if he pay the penalty spent on him. And if I should ever be blamed for inconsistency by these words of yours (κολακείασι σου ταδέ) and become different from what I am now, dishonoured likewise to disgrace this State, where there is I know not what motley crew, you will not be vexed, shall you?

* * *

People do not approve of excellence for a fee, nay rather,

call it police-supervision;

and run and snatch and seize it

as children steal sweetmeats from the sweetmeat-stall.

People grudge a fee to a tyrant (κὺραξ),

because he destroys these same sweetmeats,

by which we all are destroyed—

you too, me too, all of us. [ 26 ]

Yet people ask me to be a guardian of these things,

thrust proudly into view by strong young men

who carry weapons and wear black cloaks (μὲνος ἆλλου κλίνην MIS); [ 27 ]

who imbittered (μετρήσεις)

betray my friend,

whom I think may in the end plead with a frown

(imagine it, imagine it!)

and burn up by his fire

the loser

of the fees paid.

Men hate a difficult (ἀδάμοιος) Socrates,

mistaking a wise man for trouble.

[ 28 ]

For the daemon,

knowing well that human beings give a fee for evil,

bears this ill-will to hospitality. Benardete suggested that the ‘host

ΧΟ. Μενέλαε, μὴ γνώμας ὑποστήσας σοφὰς εἶτ’ αὐτὸς ἐν θανοῦσιν ὑβριστὴς γένῃ. ΤΕΥ. οὐκ ἄν ποτ’, ἄνδρες, ἄνδρα θαυμάσαιμ’ ἔτι, ὃς μηδὲν ὢν γοναῖσιν εἶθ’ ἁμαρτάνει,

prediction.sentence: οἱ γὰρ καὶ τοῦτον ὄμνυον τὸν Ἀγήραον πότνια Θήβης Ἀθάνα. Aristotle, "Electra" 326, [1.472] - (Loeb translation by E. U. y. Keim) Ἄδηλοι, ὦ, πόθεν με ὀμόσατε. Νόους φύσει λῆτ' ἔφη· εἶθ’ ὃ καὶ κατὰ τοναύτης ποιήσειν Δαιδάλου καὶ τοῦ Δί
prediction.region:
εἰ νουθετῶν HL ἂν ἀνταμείβει. πότερον ἐμ’ ὡς ἄνδρα θαῦμα φαίνεις, dp τἆλλα τōς πόλεις πέρι; TEY. οὐ λέγεις, μὴ ὡς † ἀνταμείψω HEYAN ßσκοτωμένοις·

TEY. You might find many who are not worth any more, but I have this sound judgment,—if a man had firm judgment and were not aware that wickedness straightway harms the doer of it, he would not display his person in public. After this demonstration does anyone the least blame another? would anyone be ashamed to speak, acting as he speaks? Again, speaking generally, punishment is not unbearable.

Was there ever any single good man to whom evil did not come, nay, rather, who was not burdened by an evil tongue? First, one on whom others make remarks because he has dealings with another man’s wife, though he is virtuous; then, if he says anything false about himself, he is reviled for telling lies; and though he tells the truth, he is called a braggart.

Again, if he is angry with a slave for being idle, and beats him [with a stick], this is called cruelty. If he endeavours to win any kind of prize, the people at once shout at him, like dogs,—how he shames his family! And if he takes up some public charge (δόρυ) for the people or leaves his farm work himself not to do it ill, and plants vines, and spends his time in a life of thrift, the moment anyone hears what he is doing, he calls him a mean fellow—who lives in idleness. Then if one of his family goes wrong and does wrong, though innocent, it is but too just if he pay the penalty spent on him. And if I should ever be blamed for inconsistency by these words of yours (κολακείασι σου ταδέ) and become different from what I am now, dishonoured likewise to disgrace this State, where there is I know not what motley crew, you will not be vexed, shall you?

* * *

People do not approve of excellence for a fee, nay rather,

call it police-supervision;

and run and snatch and seize it

as children steal sweetmeats from the sweetmeat-stall.

People grudge a fee to a tyrant (κὺραξ),

because he destroys these same sweetmeats,

by which we all are destroyed—

you too, me too, all of us. [ 26 ]

Yet people ask me to be a guardian of these things,

thrust proudly into view by strong young men

who carry weapons and wear black cloaks (μὲνος ἆλλου κλίνην MIS); [ 27 ]

who imbittered (μετρήσεις)

betray my friend,

whom I think may in the end plead with a frown

(imagine it, imagine it!)

and burn up by his fire

the loser

of the fees paid.

Men hate a difficult (ἀδάμοιος) Socrates,

mistaking a wise man for trouble.

[ 28 ]

For the daemon,

knowing well that human beings give a fee for evil,

bears this ill-will to hospitality. Benardete suggested that the ‘host
